headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GIARRAPUTO, LEONARD T.
summary: GIARRAPUTO--Leonard Thomas, on March 22, 2014, Leonard Thomas Giarraputo, of Reistertown, Maryland, Broadcasting Executive; beloved husband of Joy Civitella; devoted father of Barbara McLennan and Mark Giarraputo; loving grandfather of Ashley Horton, William McLennan, Jr., Cameron and Matthew Giarraputo. A memorial service will be held 10:30am, Wednesday, March 26, at St. Francis Xavier Church-Hunt Valley, MD. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Leonard's name may be made to HHT Foundation International Inc. (Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome) or Guiding Eyes For The Blind.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MAZZOLA, ANTHONY A.
summary: MAZZOLA--Anthony T., Former editor in chief of Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR, and the curator of Hearst Corporation's fine art collection, died May 21 in New York. He was 90. "Anthony Mazzola was a dynamic member of the Hearst Magazines family for more than 65 years," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. "Tony will be missed by everyone who had the pleasure of working with him." Frank A. Bennack, Jr., former CEO and now executive vice chairman of Hearst Corporation, added, "Tony Mazzola's contributions to Harper's BAZAAR and Town&Country have not only influenced those titles as they appear even today but our entire magazine business." Mazzola, the editor who defined affluence and style for millions of readers at the two magazines for 44 years, started his career at Hearst as an art director. In 1948, at the age of 25, Mazzola joined Town&Country as the youngest art director in the magazine's history. He held that post for nearly two decades, ultimately becoming editor in chief in 1965. Town&Country is the longest continuously published general-interest magazine in America, having been founded in 1846. "Tony Mazzola was one of the most creative editors I've known," said Hearst Corporation Director Gilbert C. Maurer. "A man of great personal style, he intuitively knew what good looked like and his work at Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR reflected that acute sensibility. Tony was a loyal friend as well as a valuable mentor to a generation of our younger talents." Building on what he once described as his "fascination with trends," Mazzola's Town&Country began to reflect the current events and social reorganization then affecting elite American society as the nation mourned the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and grappled with civil rights, the Vietnam War and the first stirrings of modern-day feminism. Mazzola said he was captivated "not by what's happening, but why." While still the magazine's art director in 1964, he published a tongue-in-cheek "It's Fun to Be Rich" issue. In 1966, his first year as Town&Country's editor in chief, he put the Rolling Stones on the cover of what was widely held to be the bible of conservative, blue-blooded America. The ensuing controversy prompted Hearst's executives to ask him, "Young man, do you know what you're doing?" "I think so," he replied. In fact, Mazzola did: By maintaining a meticulous balance between creating an exciting magazine and conveying the dignity of the subjects he presented, he broadened Town&Country's appeal and honored its audience. "People make fun of money," he once said, "but everyone forgets the good that money has done." In 1972, Mazzola was appointed editor in chief of Harper's BAZAAR and expanded his editorial style even further. He relished the opportunity to widen the magazine's scope, which he again did in 1983 by adapting its pages to reflect newly emerging trends such as the more mature, sophisticated fashions--and celebrities--of the time, and readers' increasing interest in lifestyle, as well as fashion, content. "We love the handle of being the fashion magazine with a little salt and pepper added," he said of BAZAAR in a 1983 interview. "We appeal to a woman with a very strong confidence level, who is sure of herself, not wishy-washy. She wants to know everything there is to know...and we have become the fashion and beauty book with personality, the one with heart." At the end of the decade, Mazzola again redesigned the magazine, this time to appeal to readers as they matured from trendy to classic tastes. Striving for what he called a "very unconventional, exciting visual product," Mazzola encouraged photographers such as Francesco Scavullo, Rico Puhlmann and Matthew Rolston to take dramatic, even abstract approaches to fashion. One result was a celebrated shot described by a writer as "a woman and a cabbage leaf facing off" to illustrate a story on vegetable dyes used in hair coloring. After he stepped down as editor in chief in 1992, Mazzola edited BAZAAR's 125th anniversary book in 1993. The project was both professionally and personally rewarding. "Reliving the history of this great magazine and knowing that I had a role in it is a great privilege," he said. In 1995, he was editorial director of Town&Country's two-volume 150th anniversary book. Mazzola was also the fine arts curator for Hearst Corporation, whose fine art collection emphasizes works on paper and emerging talents, many of whom have become household names since the collection was started. In addition to curating and cataloguing the collection, he produced many art and photography shows for Hearst Tower. Mazzola graduated from The Cooper Union with honors in 1948 and received The Cooper Union's distinguished alumni citation in 1992. After beginning study at The Cooper Union, he was drafted into World War II. His art background prompted an assignment to army intelligence, where he analyzed camouflage. He was awarded a Bronze Star for "meritorious achievement in connection with military operations against the enemy in Luzon, Philippine Islands." A recipient of numerous awards in the art direction and design fields, Mazzola was inducted as a Knight Officer of the Order of Merit by the Republic of Italy in 1967. He also served as a consultant and designer for such organizations as the United Nations Children's Fund, the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Princess Marcella Borghese, Inc., General Foods, Columbia Pictures, Inc. and the New York World's Fair of 1965. Mazzola is survived by his wife, Michele Morgan Mazzola, who worked with him at Hearst for over 45 years, and three children, Alisa Mazzola Mitchell, Marc Mazzola and Tony Mazzola. He is also survived by five grandchildren. There will be a private funeral in Indiana, and a memorial in New York at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 or http://www.mskcc.org/giving).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NOLAN, KATHLEEN
summary: NOLAN--Kathleen DeSales, on March 2, 2014, beloved wife of Barry Eigen; devoted mother of the late Christopher John Lenat; cherished daughter of John T. "Jack" and the late Margaret "Peggy" Nolan; dear sister of Margaret Ann Nolan, Mary Elizabeth Nolan-McGraw and Maureen Kazaras; also survived by eight nieces and nephews, two great nieces and one great-nephew. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Harry H. Witzke's Family Funeral Home, Inc., 4112 Old Columbia Pike, Ellicott City, MD. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday at 11am at St. John's Episcopal Church. Interment Dulaney Valley Memorial Gardens. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church for Pastoral Care, 9120 Frederick Rd., Ellicott City, MD 21042 or Our Daily Bread Employment Center, 725 The Fallsway, Baltimore, MD 21202 or online at www.catholiccharities-md.org/ our-daily-bread/

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COURTENAY, ELAINE K.
summary: COURTENAY--Elaine K.,86, passed away April, 17th, 2014 in New York City. She was born in Rochester, NY on February 4th, 1928. She was raised in Barrington, Il where she graduated from high school. She attended Knox College in Illinois and Northwestern University before heading to New York City. She worked for General Cable of New York and AT&T. Elaine was an avid patron of the arts and founded Courtenay Artists, Inc., a talent agency, and she placed many famous singers and opera stars. She was preceded in death by her loving husband James Clark Courtenay, Jr., formerly of Louisville, KY, and her parents Mabel Barron and Charles Kerry. She is survived by her sister Linda Truxell of Livonia, MI; brothers Warren Kerry of Daytona Beach, FL, John Kerry of Treasure Island, FL, and several close nieces and nephews, and her beloved Papillon dog, Coquine Posy. The family wishes to express special thanks to her wonderful caregiver and friend, Candice Hutcherson. Services were held yesterday at the Embry-Bosse Funeral Home, 2723 Preston Highway, Louisville, KY followed by burial at Cave Hill Cemetery next to her beloved husband Jim. Memorial gifts may be made to Papillon Haven Rescue, c/o Jan Jordan, P.O. Box 20306, Hot Springs, AR 71903.

headline: Google’s Video of Its Self-Driving Car
summary: The company has begun building a fleet of experimental electric-powered vehicles that can’t be driven by people and are summoned with a smartphone app.

headline: At the RSA Security Conference, Things Get Testy and Then They Get Awkward
summary: A look at some of the highlights, lowlights and more awkward happenings that took place at the annual RSA security conference this week.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Bulkier Brows, Harry Brant’s Runway Moment and Dries Van Noten’s Curator Cameo
summary: Plus, why Coach is more popular than Gucci in China, who sat in H&M’s front row and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.

headline: Engineers Allege Hiring Collusion in Silicon Valley
summary: A class-action suit by Silicon Valley engineers against companies including Google, Apple and Intel has revealed details of an agreement among them not to cold-call one another’s employees.

headline: Also on the Menu at Empire Diner: New Memories
summary: The sound of first dates, business trips and strangers shooting the breeze fill a landmark spot in Chelsea.

headline: A Window-Washing Service on Two Wheels
summary: A bicycle is the way to travel for Phil Prado, a window-washer with clients all over Lower Manhattan and Midtown.

headline: Giving Early Taste of G.O.P. Tactics, Texans Make a Stand Against Obama
summary: During this primary election cycle, Republican candidates in Texas have rallied around common villains — President Obama and the federal government.

headline: Buffett’s ‘Three T’s’ Open Up on CNBC
summary: The Berkshire executives Ted Weschler, Todd Combs and Tracy Britt Cool gave a rare interview on Monday.

headline: On GrubHub and Seamless, Restaurants Pay for Placement
summary: Restaurants that pay bigger commissions end up higher in search results.

headline: In Change, Tourre Won’t Be Teaching University of Chicago Course
summary: The former Goldman Sachs trader had been scheduled to teach an undergraduate course on economic analysis beginning March 31. But a University of Chicago spokesman said on Tuesday that he would no longer be an instructor.

headline: Sol Campbell’s Surprising Charge of Racism
summary: Few expected the former England captain to charge in his new biography that racism had kept him from leading England more often.

headline: Examining a Generation Tied to Smartphones
summary: AT&T is introducing a major effort that highlights how connected young Americans are to their devices.

headline: Top Official Can’t Rule on Cable Merger
summary: The Justice Department official, William Baer, represented NBCUniversal during its takeover by Comcast and is therefore forbidden from considering the merger.

headline: Jeff Lawson of Twilio: When Ideas Collide, Don’t Duck
summary: “Conflict shouldn’t be taboo,” says the chief executive of a cloud communications company. “In fact, resolving conflict is one of the key things companies do.”

headline: Sprint Owner’s New Appeal for Merger With T-Mobile
summary: Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank, took an unusual tack in a rare address to an American audience on Tuesday, saying that he wants to rescue the United States from broadband oblivion.

headline: Daily Report: Sprint’s Owner Makes New Case for Merger with T-Mobile
summary: Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank, took an unusual tack in a rare address to an American audience on Tuesday, saying that he wants to rescue the United States from broadband oblivion.

headline: Standing for More Than a Century, Only to Vanish in an Instant
summary: The two buildings that were wiped out by an explosion had been fixtures on their block in East Harlem since 1910.

headline: Action Cameras, for When a Smartphone Won’t Be Able to Keep Up
summary: A review of five cameras that are in the same price range but offer different features.

headline: Pharrell’s Phragrance, Karl’s Custom Emojis and Obama’s Shopping Trip
summary: Plus, Vogue Italia’s controversy-baiting editorial, Tehran goes mad for models and more from the week in style.

headline: Snapchat Settlement With F.T.C.
summary: The mobile messaging service Snapchat settled with the Federal Trade Commission over charges that the service inaccurately claimed that, once sent, messages disappeared.

headline: Was There a Gangster Called Oscar the Poet?
summary: Readers ask questions about a gang leader caught carrying a book of poems as well as the reason for green lights outside police precinct stations.

headline: Shawn Jenkins of Benefitfocus: A C.E.O. Is Like a Flight Instructor
summary: The chief executive of a benefits technology company says good leaders let employees learn by experience. “I’ve got to be willing to let you fail a pretty good amount, almost to the point of danger,” he says.

headline: Reading, Writing and Renewal (the Urban Kind)
summary: A new public school that also includes a community center and other public amenities is part of a joint project designed to revitalize a blighted section of East Baltimore.

headline: How to Profit Modestly by Moving to a Nonprofit
summary: Colleges across the country offer programs intended to prepare unemployed corporate professionals, or those looking to make career transitions, for the expanding nonprofit sector.

headline: 350 Rose Petals Packed Into a Single Jar of Moisturizing Balm
summary: The new Aerin Essentials Collection includes Rose Balm, a super-hydrating product that also serves as the base for a new set of 10 lipsticks.

headline: Free-for-All on the Final Friday of Tribeca Film Festival
summary: As the presenting sponsor of the festival for the first time, the company is introducing an effort, “Film for All,” that aims to expose the festival to more New Yorkers.

headline: Judge Sides with F.T.C. in Payday Lending Case
summary: A federal judge has reinforced the Federal Trade Commission’s authority to go after payday lenders that claim their ties to Native American tribes make them immune to laws restricting high-cost loans.

headline: Odd Birds
summary: Willy Puchner’s “ABC of Fabulous Princesses” imagines princesses as exotic birds, and Kate Samworth’s “Aviary Wonders Inc.” takes the form of a manual for building your own birds.

headline: Can You Trust ‘Secure’ Messaging Apps?
summary: Messaging apps and security are two of the hottest topics in tech. But can you trust the wave of supposedly secure messaging services coming out now? The New York Times’s Molly Wood talks to an expert.

headline: Breaking From Donor Dependence
summary: Institutions grapple with expanding their profit-making activities as government and private financing dwindles.

headline: Golden Gate Buys Stake in Parent of Ann Taylor
summary: Golden Gate, the private equity firm, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it had purchased a roughly 9.5 percent stake in Ann Inc., with the aim of bolstering the retailer’s stock price.

headline: Art Book Depicting Murder Inc. Is No Steal
summary: The collector’s edition of “The Brownsville Boys: Jewish Gangsters of Murder, Inc.” is lavishly illustrated, printed and boxed, and sells for $4,200 per copy.

headline: Time Inc. May Join Media Exodus to Lower Manhattan
summary: After being a fixture in Midtown Manhattan for more than seven decades, the magazine publisher is considering relocating to an area that has become a lower-cost alternative for corporations.

headline: Douglas Merrill of ZestFinance: Steer Clear of What You Can’t Measure
summary: The chief of a big-data company says using processes that can’t be quantified often means you aren’t asking the right questions.

headline: Health Care Shares Pull Down Indexes
summary: Questions about a hepatitis C drug affects biotech companies.

headline: Sit Back and Soak Awhile in Natural Springs
summary: An ancient practice is revived by travelers interested in natural treatments.

headline: Real Estate Developers in Movieland
summary: Some whose day job is putting up buildings have also found their way into show business. And it’s a labor of love.

headline: Risks Abound as Reporters Play in Traffic
summary: The availability of ready metrics on content is not only changing the way news organizations compensate their employees, but will have a significant effect on the news itself.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Failure Fetish
summary: How to start a delivery business. How to find happiness after selling a business. Is a third of all Internet traffic bogus?

headline: The Women on the Sidelines of the Hobby Lobby Case
summary: Business owners aren’t the only people who will be affected by the Supreme Court’s take on the contraceptive mandate.

headline: Minecraft Maker Won’t Work With a Facebook-Owned Oculus VR
summary: Like many game makers who were considering working with the Oculus virtual-reality tools, Markus Persson is uncomfortable with Facebook’s ad-driven business model.

headline: Can’t Play by the Rules? It’s Fine by Mr. Monopoly
summary: Hasbro, the maker of the classic board game, will ask players to debate their favorite “house rules” for inclusion as options in a future edition.

headline: Adviser on Dell Buyout Questions a Tumultuous Process
summary: At the Tulane Corporate Law Institute, an adviser on Dell’s leveraged buyout wondered whether the myriad steps the board took to ensure the integrity of the sales process could have been improved.

headline: Dealing With Online Reviews: ‘You Can’t Take This Personally’
summary: The founder of a company that helps people and businesses control their online reputations recommends acknowledging errors.

headline: Consortium Wants Standards for ‘Internet of Things’
summary: Some of the largest multinational corporations have formed a global standards body intended to speed the connection of factories, oil rigs and hospitals to intricate systems of sensors and computers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Can Bookstores Survive?
summary: Etsy collaborates with the enemy. Connecticut raises its minimum wage. How to find the right accountant for your business.

headline: Smartphones, the Disappointing Miracle
summary: People from Earth’s most remote corners have something in common: They all download apps, interacting with the mobile Internet billions of times a day, and they all feel frustration at slow loads and app crashes. A new report shows how much work it is, getting us to this level of frustration.

headline: The Tech Bubble’s Silver Lining: Cheap Services for Everyone

summary: Texas is at the forefront of a national initiative to modernize the call system to accommodate situations in which a voice call may be risky or impossible and to be more accessible to the deaf community.

headline: All Paths Lead to Illumination
summary: “Mastering Light: From the Natural to the Artificial” at Vassar’s Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center in Poughkeepsie is a quirky, thought-provoking show that divides its subject into three sometimes overlapping areas.
